Situation Report
-2
March 5-6, 1973: Governing Board group meets in Washington
with a group of about 100 TV Board Members and Managers to
discuss Palm Beach Accord and plans for a new TV licensee
^organization governed by an all lay board. Group votes
approval.
March 6, 1973: Rogers Committee meets again with CPB Board,
reports it has been successful in getting the go-ahead to
establish single voice for PTV. Argument over whether CPB
can and/or should operate interconnection is inconclusive;
decision postponed until April 13 Board meeting; meanwhile
a CPB Board Committee is to work with Rogers Committee.
March "7, 1973; NAEB Executive Committee meets, has Rogers
as luncheon guest.
Those are the major meetings relevant to this situation
though there have been many more of a smaller more informal
nature. A Committee of ETS has met with Rogers to get his
reactions to their concerns; I have met with him several
times (also Friendly, Gunn) re possible NAEB relationship
to the new entity - or what we now refer to as TOP: The
Organization Proposed.
Essentially, Rogers (and Rogers jLs the Governing Board Group)
is sympathetic to involving NAEB in the new structure and to
preserving its functions. However, he rejects the idea of
having NAEB become the umbrella under which the new TV licensee
group could be established. Its structure, membership, byÂ¬
laws, etc. are far too complicated and cumbersome. He favors
restructuring PBS, whose constitution would permit an
immediate resignation of present directors so that they could
be replaced by laymen elected from the governing boards of
TV licensees. He is not unattracted by the PBS current
$9 million budget, either. He has rejected various proposals
I have made for a compromise approach in which NAEB would
remain an independent professional organization but with a
partially interlocking board of laymen. Partial pregnancy
won't work, he observes, and the only alternatives are merger
or remain completely outside.
